newsitem.title: UK: China's 96/97 grain import needs seen still high.
newsitem.headline: China's 96/97 grain import needs seen still high.

text.p: China's grain import needs could remain high in 1996/97 season even though its own grain harvest is forecast to be higher from 1995/96, a UK group said.
The Home-Grown Cereals Authority (HGCA) said China, with a population of 1.21 billion, is expected to remain as the world's top wheat importer this season.

The HGCA said although the supply/demand balance for 1996/97 indicated that China is expected to have larger export surpluses, only coarse grains exports -- rising from 350,000 tonnes to 550,000 -- are forecast to increase.
In contrast, both wheat and rice exports are forecast to fall from last year's levels.
"This is because China is unlikely to engage in too many export commitments this year in order to avoid reducing domestic stock levels too sharply," it said.
Coarse grains include barley, maize, sorghum, rye and oats.
On wheat, the HGCA said Chinese imports are forecast to be about eight million tonnes this season against the more conservative U.S. Department of Agriculture figure of seven million.
Already, purchases of about 1.5 million tonnes had been made from Canada and one million from Australia.
Only 500,000 tonnes had been purchased from the United States due to the tighter U.S. wheat balance this season and the rejection of some U.S. shipments due to quality problems.
Last season, China imported 12.6 million tonnes of wheat, most of which was sourced from Canada.
